recordings.loc: Lafayette, Boulder County, Colorado
recordings.rmk: Overcast, low cloud ceiling, and some fog; no wind; temp in mid-40s Fahrenheit. This cut starts with an American Tree Sparrow, then goes into a series of mainly or entirely White-crowned Sparrows. Low-frequency noise (talking, music, road noise) filtered out; higher-frequency hum of street lamps not filtered out. The area was brightly lit, probably contributing to the high calling rate. Note: I answered "yes" to "Bird Seen?" but I note that all I could see was forms above the lights.

recordings.loc: Vancouver Island (near  Victoria), Capital, British Columbia
recordings.rmk: Single individual offering two songs, while moving from tree to tree within 50 meter area.  Singing only briefly before flying to nearby trees, pausing for several minutes before singing briefly, and then flying again.  Quite different for this individual who typically remains perched in one of a few places and sings regularly for long periods.  They are several other individuals within 150-200 meters today: is this individual defining its territory?

recordings.loc: Rainbow Park (near  Victoria), Capital, British Columbia
recordings.rmk: Begging calls from single juvenile.  I have been watching the nest: this juvenile left the nest about 8 days ago.  It lacks flight feathers and spends most of the time hiding under dense shrubs.  At the beginning of the recording, the juvenile calls occasionally while the adult feeds on the open grass 5 to 10 meters away.  Toward the last portion of the recording, the adult returns to the juvenile, at which point the juvenile calls continuously, the adult opens its mouth, and juvenile feeds.  Afterwards, the adult departs and the begging calls cease.  I used a moderate high pass filter at  4000 Hz to reduce noise from three floatplanes.

recordings.rmk: These birds are migrating  in my city in may.  I caught this recording accidentaly when I was filming some pine siskin taking a bath.  From one of my house window, i place my microphone through the window opening.  One white-crowned sparrow began to sing really close from my mic, from about 1 metre.  I had to reduce the gain not to have the recording too loud.  This male was responding to another male singning in the background.  I have maid two separate recordings from the original.  The first one is untouched.  The second one was amplified.  You can hear pine siskins taking a bath in the background

recordings.loc: Oxford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk:
Foraging around partridgepea plants (*Chamaecrista fasciculata*). Perched briefly in a small sapling, 1.5m above the ground. Among a mixed-species flock of sparrows. 

#Habitat#
State waterfowl refuge along the margins of USACE flood control reservoir. Strip along the lake margins ~1km wide of moist soil grassland with mix of forbs, native warm season grasses (Andropogon, Schyzachyrium, Eragrostis, Aristida, etc.), and some sparse woody vegetation (Cephalanthus, Quercus saplings, etc.) bounded by oak hickory forest and, in places, pine plantation.  Three or four shallow waterfowl impoundments partially flooded in the winter.

#Editing#
Edited in Adobe Audition. Butterworth high-pass filter, order 3, cutoff frequency 700 Hz. 

#Equipment#
Fostex FR-2 digital recorder with Sennheiser microphone and Telinga pro 22" parabolic reflector.

recordings.file-name: XC573692-Z leucophrys nuttalli  2020-07-05 Oakland, CA, USA  mp3.mp3
recordings.rmk:
Recorded at the weedy edge of a manicured golf course; trees are Black Acacia, Red-flowering Gum, Coastal Redwood, Coastal Live Oak.  The adult bird was singing from the interior of a Scrub Oak or from the lower branches of a Red-flowering Gum while an immature bird was feeding below much of the time.  The adult had white crown stripes, a yellow bill, gray chest, streaked back, brown flanks, and very short primary coverts.   Probable male song.

The recording was trimmed and amplified to -.3dB, and the recording was made from about 10-15 feet of the singing bird.

recordings.loc: Happy Valley-Goose Bay, Division No. 10, Newfoundland and Labrador
recordings.rmk:
This is a very strange recording of a White-crowned Sparrow.  Rinchen Boardman and I came across this bird and puzzled over its identity for several minutes, before finally getting visual confirmation of it, and watching it sing its strange song through our binoculars.

Remarkably, this appears to be the first recording of White-crowned Sparrow from Labrador in the xeno-canto archive. However, it by no means is a typical song from this region. We heard many other White-crowned Sparrows in Goose Bay and on the eastern shore near Mary's Harbour, etc., that hardly resemble the bizarre monotonous song preserved in this recording.

recordings.loc: FR-2061, Deschutes National Forest, Deschutes County, Oregon
recordings.rmk: Grabbed from video with Canon PowerShot SX50 HS, filtered and edited for handling noise and for a shorter interval with Audacity. This dialect is very different from the birds in the Willamette Valley to the coast, but it's an astonishingly close match to recordings from the Puget Sound area and Vancouver Island. Yellow bill, narrower white lateral head stripes, and pale gray lores and supraloral were obvious in the field. Oriantha does not occur anywhere near here, despite the range map here, which is incorrect. The tongue extending down from NE Oregon should stop east of Bend and Prineville (not connect to the Cascades) and then extend southward from there to connect to the north-central and northeastern California populations. And considering the dialect of this bird, there should be a narrow finger extending southward through the Washington and Oregon Cascades.

recordings.rmk:
About 20 immature Gambel's White-crowned Sparrows were in the area (no adults present). A few adult and immature Pugetensis White-crowned Sparrows were also nearby. This is probably one of the better general areas for Gambel's White-crowneds in Santa Cruz County, although it is likely that Pugetensis still usually outnumber them.

Recorded with a Sennheiser shotgun mic and a Marantz PMD661 Recorder from the UC Santa Cruz Biology Teaching Lab. Recorded as a WAV file, converted to mp3.

recordings.loc: El Sobrante, Contra Costa County, California
recordings.file-name: XC573700-WCSP nuttalli 6_27_20 El Sobrante, CA USA.mp3
recordings.rmk:
The recording was trimmed and amplified to -.3 dB; there is car traffic back round noise.    This is a call note that is different than the migratory Z.l pugetensis; I observed the bird as it repeatedly made the call.

There are 2 adults and 1 immature bird at this location, an closed nursery, approximately 2 miles from the nearest shoreline.  These birds are across the street from my work, and I heard them for the first time last year (after being at this location for 33 years).  The recording was made from the top of an 8 foot fence along a busy street. The main vegetation is low ornamental shrubs, with Pittosporum the only species that I could identify.  The old nursery has shrubbery inside the fence, and the birds fly back and forth from there to a large tree across the street.  Adult bird had black and white head stripes, a yellow bill, streaked back, and a short primary projection.

Whistler, Squamish-Lillooet, British Columbia
recordings.rmk: This recording was not significantly modified. The White-crowned Sparrow in question here was observed in a fairly urban environment, particularly close to the Whistler Public Library and a road (you can hear a car starting in the recording). There is a small park nearby, with spruce and birch trees, as well as various shrubbery that I am not horticulturally skilled enough to name. I did not see the bird, I only heard it singing. I am fairly certain this was a male bird, but since female song is known from this species, and since I am unfamiliar with it, I'd prefer to leave this at "sex uncertain." The weather was clear, approaching sunset as I recall.

recordings.loc: Nadahini River, Haines Road, British Columbia
Peckham Road, Santa Cruz County, California
recordings.rmk:
About 20 immature Gambel's White-crowned Sparrows were in the area (no adults present). A few adult and immature Pugetensis White-crowned Sparrows were also nearby. This is probably one of the better general areas for Gambel's White-crowneds in Santa Cruz County, although it is likely that Pugetensis still usually outnumber them.

Recorded with a Sennheiser shotgun mic and a Marantz PMD661 Recorder from the UC Santa Cruz Biology Teaching Lab. Recorded as a WAV file, converted to mp3.
